attributes.title: Maternal and neonatal data collection systems in low- and middle-income countries: scoping review protocol
attributes.description: Scoping Review protocol:A scoping review will be conducted based on established methodology. Multiple databases of indexed and grey literature will be searched with a specific focus on existing electronic and paper-electronic systems in LMICs that collect continuous, prospective, and individual-level data from antenatal care, delivery, neonatal care (up to 28 days), and postpartum (up to 42 days) at the facility and community level, at the national and district level, and at large hospitals. Also, experts will be contacted to identify unpublished information on relevant data collection systems. General and specific descriptions of Health Information Systems (HIS) extracted from the different sources will be combined and duplicated HIS will be removed, producing a list of unique statements. We will present a final list of Maternal, Newborn, and Child Health systems considered flexible enough to be updated with necessary improvements to detect, assess and respond to safety concerns during the introduction of vaccines and other maternal health interventions. Selected experts will participate in an in-person consultation meeting to select up to three systems to be further explored in situ. Results and knowledge gaps will be synthesized after expert consultation

attributes.title: Investigating effects of round ($150.00), just-below ($149.99), and precise ($151.11) prices on the evaluation of an online shop.

q1.value: Investigating effects of round ($150.00), just-below ($149.99), and precise ($151.11) prices on the evaluation of an online shop.

q2.value: Luise Kirsten, David D. Loschelder, Marie-Lena Frech

q3.value:
Price is an influential parameter for purchase decisions, which is why it is an important part of consumer research.  In pricing studies, a distinction is usually made between three basic pricing strategies: of round ($150.00), just-below ($149.99), and precise ($151.11) prices. However, the research results on effectiveness of the respective strategies are not unequivocal.

A pervasive pricing strategy in retail are just below prices (Holdershaw, Gendall & Garland, 1997). According to so called level or first digit effects people round prices down or focus on the leftmost digit which lead to a preference of just below prices as they were perceived as lower than round prices (Schindler & Wiman, 1989).

Another theory documents an association mechanism of the price and quality image of products. This theory argues that just below prices are perceived as low, discount prices and thus have a more advantageous price image compared to round prices. In contrast, round prices are associated with high quality and thus outperform just below prices regarding the quality image (Schindler & Kibarian, 2001).

However, little knowledge has been gained so far about precise prices. Studies on price precision in negotiations have found that precision is associated with competence and fairness (Loschelder, Friese, Schaerer & Galinsky, 2016). In line with these “attribution-of-competence” findings one could assume that precise prices in retail lead to a better evaluation of the price and quality image in contrast to round prices. 

Another theory argues that precise prices could inhibit the processing fluency or irritate consumers due to this unfamiliar pricing strategy (Wahdhwa & Zhang, 2015). This is accompanied by the high number of products in an online shop. For this reason, the price and quality image as well as the purchase intention could also be worse compared to round and just below prices.

The present study examines to which extent different prices (round/just below/precise/11-ending) influence the price and quality image of an online shop and the purchase intention. The main focus is on precise prices.

q4.value:
Confirmatory Hypotheses: 

Round vs. just below prices

Based on image effects, we would predict that...
H 1a: Just below prices lead to a more advantageous price image perception of an online shop than round prices.
H 1b: Just below prices lead to less advantageous quality image perception of an online shop than round prices.
H 1c:  Just below prices lead to higher purchase intention in an online shop than round prices.

Exploratory Hypotheses: 

Round vs. precise prices 
One can develop competing hypotheses:

Based on attribution-of-competence theory, we would predict that... 
H 2a: Precise prices lead to a more advantageous price image and quality image of an online shop and higher purchase intention than round prices.

Based on processing fluency theory, we would predict that... 
H 2b: Precise prices lead to a less advantageous price image and quality image of an online shop and lower purchase intention than round prices.


Precise vs. just below prices
One can develop competing hypotheses:

Based on attribution-of-competence theory, we would predict that... 
H 3a: Precise prices lead to a more advantageous price image and quality image of an online shop and higher purchase intention than just below prices.

Based on processing fluency theory, we would predict that... 
H 3b: Precise prices lead to a less advantageous price image and quality image of an online shop and lower purchase intention than just below prices.


11-ending prices
H 4a: We will examine whether 11-ending or round prices lead to a more advantageous price image and quality image of an online shop and higher purchase intention.
H 4b: We will examine whether 11-ending or just below prices lead to a more advantageous price image and quality image of an online shop and higher purchase intention.
H 4c: We will examine whether 11-ending or precise prices lead to a more advantageous price image and quality image of an online shop and higher purchase intention.


Shop evaluation
H 5: We will examine whether the shop evaluation influences the evaluation of one single product in the online shop.

question.value:
Participants are recruited through Prolific. Participants will be payed £0.80 for a completed submission of the online survey. 

Inclusion criteria are the following: 

Nationality: United States
Literacy Difficulties: No
First Language: English
Approval Rate: 95 % -100 %
Number of previous submissions: 100 - 1000

q13.value: Our target sample size is 232 participants. We will attempt to assess at least 260 participants, assuming that there might be invalid responses or participants which do not complete the whole questionnaire.

q14.value: We conducted sample size analysis in G*Power, striving for a power of 0.90 with an alpha (type-I) error level of 0.05. We assume a moderate effect size of f=0.25 (d=0.50) according to Cohen’s conventions. Based on these parameters, the ANOVA with four measurement points (round/just below/precise/11-ending price) has three numerator dfs and G*Power yields a required total sample size of 232.

q15.value: Data collection will be terminated after one week of assessment. If we do not reach the required sample size in this time frame, data collection will be terminated upon reaching the goal of 260 participants. Excess participants beyond 260 will be retained in the data sample and yield higher power and/or a higher chance to detect a smaller effect size. All data exclusions will be disclosed transparently and follow the pre-defined criteria listed below.

question.value: We will manipulate price endings (round/just below /precise/11-ending) by assigning participants randomly to one of those four conditions. In the precise condition, half of the prices will be slightly lower, and the other half will be slightly higher than the round prices. The total sum of the individual prices will not exceed a deviation of 10 cents to round condition.

We will examine three main dependent variables: 1. price image, 2. quality image and 3. purchase intention. These variables will be assessed for the whole shop as well as for a single product out of a range of products. For the items a 7-point Likert-scale (1= strongly disagree, 7 = strongly agree) will be used. 

1.     Price Image 
This shop…
a.	...offers products on sale.
b.	...has recently decreased prices.
c.	...has the lowest prices compared to other shops.
d.	...has fair prices.

This product…
e.	…is on sale.
f.	...was recently reduced in price.
g.	...has the lowest price someone can find.
h.	...has a fair price.

2.     Quality Image
This shop…
a.	...only sells high-quality products.
b.	...is classy.
c.	...has an overall high quality.
d.     ...has a higher quality compared to other shops.

This product…
e.	…is of high quality.
f.	…is durable.
g.	…is made of high-quality materials.
h.	…has the highest quality someone can find.

3.     Purchase intention
a.	This shop motivates me to buy something.
b.	This product motivates me to buy it for the advertised price.

Additionally, we will assess control variables (7-point Likert scale; 1 = strongly disagree, 7 = strongly agree) about online shopping behavior, average spending and convenience consciousness. Finally, we will assess demographics (e.g., age, gender, income).

4.     Control/Sociodemographic
a.	How much do you spend typically for one necklace?
b.	I make most of my purchases online.
c.	I always pay attention to the price, when I buy something. 
d.	I often compare prices of various shops.
e.	I want as little effort as possible when shopping.
f.	Convenience (ease) is particularly important to me when shopping.

We will conduct a factor analysis on the items of price image and quality image to test whether the items are associated with the same construct. If they load on the same single factor, these items will be combined into one scale for price image and one scale for quality image. (CronbachsAlpha)

An analysis of variance (ANOVA) with the four conditions (round/just below /precise/11-ending)  as a between-participant’s factor and price image, quality image, and purchase intention as dependent variable will be conducted.

Contrast analysis will be used to compare the four groups (Hypothesis 1a-1c: round group = +1; just below group = -1, precise group = 0, 11-ending = 0; Hypothesis 2a-2b: round group = +1; just-below group = 0, precise group = -1, 11-ending = 0; Hypothesis 3a-3b: round group = 0; just-below group = -1, precise group = +1, 11-ending = 0); Hypothesis 4a: round group = -1; just-below group = 0, precise group = 0, 11-ending = +1; Hypothesis 4b: round group = 0; just-below group = -1, precise group = 0, 11-ending = +1); Hypothesis 4c: round group = 0; just-below group = 0, precise group = -1, 11-ending = +1)

q21.value: We will use the standard p < .05 criteria (one-tailed).

q22.value:
We will exclude outliers exceeding > 2.5 SDs of their respective group mean.
We will include awareness checks to proof if all participants have read carefully the questions.

q23.value: Missing data should be avoided by participants having to answer each item in the online survey to proceed with the questionnaire.

attributes.title: Suicide and self-harm amongst people with alcohol dependence and/or opioid use disorder: CPRD studies with linked HES and ONS data

q1.value: A longitudinal study of suicide and self-harm amongst people with alcohol dependence and/or opioid use disorder in England between 1998-2018

q2.value: Prianka Padmanathan, Harriet Forbes, David Gunnell, Paul Moran, Rachael Hughes, Matthew Hickman

q3.value: Alcohol dependence and opioid use disorder are both problematic worldwide and have substantial negative consequences at an individual and societal level. People with alcohol dependence or opioid use disorder are at substantially increased risk of suicide and non-fatal self-harm. However, current suicide estimates are mainly based on data from outside England and comprehensive up-to-date data from England is lacking. This is particularly important because in recent years there have been both substantial reductions to drug and alcohol services in England and an upward trend in drug-related deaths. It is unclear whether an increase in suicides amongst people with alcohol dependence or opioid use disorder has contributed to this trend. To inform suicide prevention strategies, it is important to obtain accurate information about the nature and extent of the problem. This study will, therefore, investigate the rate and time trends of suicide and non-fatal self-harm amongst people with alcohol dependence and/or opioid use disorder in England.

q4.value:
Aim:
To quantify the rate of suicide and non-fatal self-harm amongst people with alcohol dependence and/or opioid use disorder in England compared with people without between 1998-2018, and to investigate variation in the rate in relation to economic and political factors.

Objectives:
1)	To estimate the incidence rates of suicide and non-fatal self-harm amongst people with alcohol dependence and/or opioid use disorder in England, and compare these rates with those occurring amongst people without alcohol dependence or opioid use disorder respectively using Cox proportional hazards regression. 
2)	To investigate the variation in the rates of suicide and non-fatal self-harm amongst people with alcohol dependence and/or opioid use disorder in England between 1998 and 2018 in relation to economic and political changes using time series models (Joinpoint regression and interrupted time-series analysis). 

The following hypotheses are deduced from existing literature.
Primary hypothesis: The rate of suicide and self-harm is higher amongst people with alcohol dependence and/or opioid use disorder compared to people without.

The secondary hypotheses are that the rate of suicide and self-harm is:
•	higher post-2008 due to the impact of the global financial crisis. 
•	highest post-2012 due to the impact of financial cuts to services after the introduction of the Health and Social Care Act.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
Objective 1: matched retrospective cohort 
Objective 2: time series

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

question.value:
Study population:
The study population will be restricted to patients of at least 18 years of age. Patients in the exposed group will enter on the latest date out of index date (i.e. date of diagnosis), current registration date or 2nd January 1998. 2nd January has been selected because it is the earliest date for which both HES and ONS linked mortality data are available. We considered including the time prior to the index event within our model as unexposed time but chose not to due to concerns regarding the reliability of the index date. 

To ensure adequate power, prevalent cases will be included in the primary analysis i.e. records will be included even if the index date is before the date of current registration. A sensitivity analysis will be conducted with only incident cases (i.e. only records where the index date is at least one year after the date of current registration).

Patients will be followed-up until whichever occurs first out of: the end of the study period, the last date of data collection from the practice, transfer away from the practice or death using the ONS date. For analyses of suicide data, the study period will end in November 2017, one year before the most recent date for which HES and ONS mortality linked data are both available (Nov 2018). This will allow for the potential time lags in suicides being included in ONS death registration. 

Comparison group:
There will be up to 10 unexposed patients matched to every exposed patient. The comparison group will also be restricted to people aged at least 18 years and matched on calendar year at cohort entry and general practice at current registration. Patients in the unexposed group will inherit the index date of the exposed patient to whom they have been matched.

q13.value:
Objective 1

Exposure: Alcohol dependence
The feasibility count identified 73,308 people with alcohol dependence and linked ONS and HES data. The risk of suicide in England in 2017 was approximately 10 per 100,000 population.11 People with alcohol dependence are believed to be at up to 10 times greater risk of suicide,2 therefore we estimate there will be approximately (100/100000)*73308=) 73 suicide deaths within this cohort between 1998-2017. 

A crude power calculation using the following command on Stata:
power twoproportions p1, n(numlist) power(numlist)
P1 (proportion in control group) = 10/100,000=0.0001
Power(numlist)=0.8; Alpha=0.05; N(numlist)=73,308 people x 5 years follow up on average17 x 2 (due to 1:1 controls)=733,080

Demonstrates a sufficient size to detect: 
A minimum estimated experimental group proportion=0.00018 (2 s.f.)
A minimum risk ratio detectable in population=1.8 (2.s.f.) 

Exposure: Opioid use disorder
The feasibility count identified 28,994 people with opioid use disorder and linked ONS and HES data. If people with opioid use disorder are at 7 times greater risk of suicide,2 based on the feasibility counts, we estimate there will be ((70/100000)* 28,994 =) 20 suicides amongst this group between 1998-2017. 

Using the above power command on Stata where: 
P1 (proportion in control group) = 10/100,000=0.0001
Power(numlist)=0.8; Alpha=0.05; N(numlist)= 28,994 people x average 5 years follow up x 2 (due to 1:1 controls)=289,940

Demonstrates a sufficient size to detect: 
A minimum estimated experimental group proportion=0.00023 (2 s.f.)
A minimum risk ratio detectable in population=2.3 (2 s.f.) 

Objective 2
A power calculation has not been provided for Objective 2 because the analysis will depend on whether significant changes in the trend in suicide rates are identified, and at which time periods these changes are observed.

question.value:
Exposure:
Alcohol dependence: Record of a Read code for alcohol dependence and linked ONS data available. 

Opioid use disorder: Record of a Read code for opioid abuse or dependence, or product code for methadone or buprenorphine on or above the recommended maintenance thresholds of 40 mg and 8 mg respectively (excluding where prescribed only as patches or injections, or there is documentation indicating the prescriptions are for pain) and linked ONS data available. 

Co-variates:
The following co-variates will be investigated as potential effect modifiers: age at cohort entry (≤45 years and >45 years, unless counts are too small in older age group, in which case ≤35 years, >35 years), sex, and previous non-fatal self-harm. If not stratified by age and sex, these factors will be included in a Cox regression model to adjust for confounding. Additionally, we will adjust for ethnicity, socioeconomic status (using Index of Multiple Deprivation score), major chronic illness score at the time of cohort entry (using Charlson Index for CPRD) & previous mental health diagnoses. 

Ethnicity will be categorised as “white” or “other” due to the potential for the analyses to be underpowered if “other” is sub-categorised. Patients may have multiple records of ethnicity between their HES and CPRD records. The patient’s overall ethnicity will be selected using the same method described in Wright et al. (2017). (Wright, Kontopantelis et al. 2017) 

Failure event:
Suicide (ONS data) and intentional non-fatal self-harm (CPRD data as the primary analysis, HES admissions data as a secondary analysis) will initially be analysed separately but may later be combined depending on power. 

When investigating overall rates of non-fatal self-harm, only the first episode of self-harm for each patient will be included. In the trends analysis, the first episode of self-harm each year will be included for each patient as in previous studies investigating rates of self-harm.

Objective 1 
Hazard ratios will be calculated for:
People with alcohol dependence compared with people without alcohol dependence.
People with opioid use disorder compared to people without opioid use disorder.
Cox regression analysis will be performed to adjust for identified confounders. Adjusted hazard ratios will be produced comparing the groups above. Calendar time from diagnosis will be included as the underlying timescale in the Cox regression.

Objective 2
Annual suicide and non-fatal self-harm rates for people with alcohol dependence or opioid use disorder and their matched controls will be calculated and plotted for each year between 1998 and 2018. The denominator for these rates will be the total number of person-years in each year. Should numbers allow, these will also be stratified by age at cohort entry (≤45 years and >45 years, unless counts are too small in older age group, in which case ≤35 years, >35 years) and gender. 

Joinpoint regression analysis will be applied to the annual rates to identify any time points in which the trend significantly changes.  Where significant changes are identified, a time-dependent categorical variable derived from the joinpoint analysis will be included as a co-variate in the Cox regression model used for objective 1. This will allow investigation of the effects of the variable whilst adjusting for potential confounders. If marked fluctuations in suicide rates between time periods are observed, an interrupted time-series analysis will be considered. The years of interest are 2008 (onset of recession) and 2013 (beginning of local authority funding cuts). 

Sensitivity analysis
To investigate the effect of bias as a result of our chosen method the following sensitivity analyses will be conducted:
1)Restrict to incident cases of alcohol dependence/opioid use disorder only i.e. records will be included only if the index event (diagnosis) occurs at least 12 months after registration.
2)Restrict to patients from up to standard practices only.
3) For the trends’ analysis, a sensitivity analysis will be cases will be censored one year after diagnosis as risk of suicide and self-harm is likely to vary with time after diagnosis.

To explore the case definition of opioid use disorder, for Objective 1, a series of sensitivity analyses will be conducted: 
1) exclude all cases with OST prescriptions, without a Read code indicating opioid misuse or dependence.
2) exclude those over 65 years, due to the possibility of medications used in OST being prescribed for pain in the older population.

It will not be possible to determine whether data regarding alcohol dependence, opioid use disorder, non-fatal self-harm, and other physical or mental health diagnoses are missing. This will be considered in the interpretation of findings.  

As suicide data will be obtained from ONS, missing data are likely to be negligible. As we are using data from acceptable patients, data is unlikely to be missing with regards to gender and year of birth. Patients with no record of sex or year of birth will be excluded. 

Patient-level Index of Multiple Deprivation (IMD) score is expected to be largely complete. Where missing, practice-level IMD will be used as a proxy. Ethnicity will be categorised as “missing” if not recorded in HES or ONS. Missing data for binary co-variates will be dealt with by coding the absence of the confounder e.g. 0 if no chronic illness recorded.

registration_responses.q1: A longitudinal study of suicide and self-harm amongst people with alcohol dependence and/or opioid use disorder in England between 1998-2018
registration_responses.q2: Prianka Padmanathan, Harriet Forbes, David Gunnell, Paul Moran, Rachael Hughes, Matthew Hickman
registration_responses.q3: Alcohol dependence and opioid use disorder are both problematic worldwide and have substantial negative consequences at an individual and societal level. People with alcohol dependence or opioid use disorder are at substantially increased risk of suicide and non-fatal self-harm. However, current suicide estimates are mainly based on data from outside England and comprehensive up-to-date data from England is lacking. This is particularly important because in recent years there have been both substantial reductions to drug and alcohol services in England and an upward trend in drug-related deaths. It is unclear whether an increase in suicides amongst people with alcohol dependence or opioid use disorder has contributed to this trend. To inform suicide prevention strategies, it is important to obtain accurate information about the nature and extent of the problem. This study will, therefore, investigate the rate and time trends of suicide and non-fatal self-harm amongst people with alcohol dependence and/or opioid use disorder in England.
registration_responses.q4:
Aim:
To quantify the rate of suicide and non-fatal self-harm amongst people with alcohol dependence and/or opioid use disorder in England compared with people without between 1998-2018, and to investigate variation in the rate in relation to economic and political factors.

Objectives:
1)	To estimate the incidence rates of suicide and non-fatal self-harm amongst people with alcohol dependence and/or opioid use disorder in England, and compare these rates with those occurring amongst people without alcohol dependence or opioid use disorder respectively using Cox proportional hazards regression. 
2)	To investigate the variation in the rates of suicide and non-fatal self-harm amongst people with alcohol dependence and/or opioid use disorder in England between 1998 and 2018 in relation to economic and political changes using time series models (Joinpoint regression and interrupted time-series analysis). 

The following hypotheses are deduced from existing literature.
Primary hypothesis: The rate of suicide and self-harm is higher amongst people with alcohol dependence and/or opioid use disorder compared to people without.

The secondary hypotheses are that the rate of suicide and self-harm is:
•	higher post-2008 due to the impact of the global financial crisis. 
•	highest post-2012 due to the impact of financial cuts to services after the introduction of the Health and Social Care Act.
registration_responses.q5: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.
q6: No blinding is involved in this study.
registration_responses.q10: Registration prior to analysis of the data
registration_responses.q13:
Objective 1

Exposure: Alcohol dependence
The feasibility count identified 73,308 people with alcohol dependence and linked ONS and HES data. The risk of suicide in England in 2017 was approximately 10 per 100,000 population.11 People with alcohol dependence are believed to be at up to 10 times greater risk of suicide,2 therefore we estimate there will be approximately (100/100000)*73308=) 73 suicide deaths within this cohort between 1998-2017. 

A crude power calculation using the following command on Stata:
power twoproportions p1, n(numlist) power(numlist)
P1 (proportion in control group) = 10/100,000=0.0001
Power(numlist)=0.8; Alpha=0.05; N(numlist)=73,308 people x 5 years follow up on average17 x 2 (due to 1:1 controls)=733,080

Demonstrates a sufficient size to detect: 
A minimum estimated experimental group proportion=0.00018 (2 s.f.)
A minimum risk ratio detectable in population=1.8 (2.s.f.) 

Exposure: Opioid use disorder
The feasibility count identified 28,994 people with opioid use disorder and linked ONS and HES data. If people with opioid use disorder are at 7 times greater risk of suicide,2 based on the feasibility counts, we estimate there will be ((70/100000)* 28,994 =) 20 suicides amongst this group between 1998-2017. 

Using the above power command on Stata where: 
P1 (proportion in control group) = 10/100,000=0.0001
Power(numlist)=0.8; Alpha=0.05; N(numlist)= 28,994 people x average 5 years follow up x 2 (due to 1:1 controls)=289,940

Demonstrates a sufficient size to detect: 
A minimum estimated experimental group proportion=0.00023 (2 s.f.)
A minimum risk ratio detectable in population=2.3 (2 s.f.) 

Objective 2
A power calculation has not been provided for Objective 2 because the analysis will depend on whether significant changes in the trend in suicide rates are identified, and at which time periods these changes are observed.

registration_responses.q12.question:
Study population:
The study population will be restricted to patients of at least 18 years of age. Patients in the exposed group will enter on the latest date out of index date (i.e. date of diagnosis), current registration date or 2nd January 1998. 2nd January has been selected because it is the earliest date for which both HES and ONS linked mortality data are available. We considered including the time prior to the index event within our model as unexposed time but chose not to due to concerns regarding the reliability of the index date. 

To ensure adequate power, prevalent cases will be included in the primary analysis i.e. records will be included even if the index date is before the date of current registration. A sensitivity analysis will be conducted with only incident cases (i.e. only records where the index date is at least one year after the date of current registration).

Patients will be followed-up until whichever occurs first out of: the end of the study period, the last date of data collection from the practice, transfer away from the practice or death using the ONS date. For analyses of suicide data, the study period will end in November 2017, one year before the most recent date for which HES and ONS mortality linked data are both available (Nov 2018). This will allow for the potential time lags in suicides being included in ONS death registration. 

Comparison group:
There will be up to 10 unexposed patients matched to every exposed patient. The comparison group will also be restricted to people aged at least 18 years and matched on calendar year at cohort entry and general practice at current registration. Patients in the unexposed group will inherit the index date of the exposed patient to whom they have been matched.
registration_responses.q17.question:
Exposure:
Alcohol dependence: Record of a Read code for alcohol dependence and linked ONS data available. 

Opioid use disorder: Record of a Read code for opioid abuse or dependence, or product code for methadone or buprenorphine on or above the recommended maintenance thresholds of 40 mg and 8 mg respectively (excluding where prescribed only as patches or injections, or there is documentation indicating the prescriptions are for pain) and linked ONS data available. 

Co-variates:
The following co-variates will be investigated as potential effect modifiers: age at cohort entry (≤45 years and >45 years, unless counts are too small in older age group, in which case ≤35 years, >35 years), sex, and previous non-fatal self-harm. If not stratified by age and sex, these factors will be included in a Cox regression model to adjust for confounding. Additionally, we will adjust for ethnicity, socioeconomic status (using Index of Multiple Deprivation score), major chronic illness score at the time of cohort entry (using Charlson Index for CPRD) & previous mental health diagnoses. 

Ethnicity will be categorised as “white” or “other” due to the potential for the analyses to be underpowered if “other” is sub-categorised. Patients may have multiple records of ethnicity between their HES and CPRD records. The patient’s overall ethnicity will be selected using the same method described in Wright et al. (2017). (Wright, Kontopantelis et al. 2017) 

Failure event:
Suicide (ONS data) and intentional non-fatal self-harm (CPRD data as the primary analysis, HES admissions data as a secondary analysis) will initially be analysed separately but may later be combined depending on power. 

When investigating overall rates of non-fatal self-harm, only the first episode of self-harm for each patient will be included. In the trends analysis, the first episode of self-harm each year will be included for each patient as in previous studies investigating rates of self-harm.

attributes.title: Evaluating CIs on Two Dimensions (Race and Sex)

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Evaluating CIs on Two Dimensions (Race and Sex)

sample.value: Because this is a data-driven statistical method (K-means clustering), it is harder to justify sample size determinations.  That said, we will aim to have 300 participants (to account for exclusions, we will recruit 325 from Amazon's mechanical Turk).

analyses.value:
Our hypothesis is that there will be three groups: White female (law-abiding), White male (the malum prohibitum crimes), and Black male (the malum in se crimes).  We will test this using K-means clustering.  In short, we will let the algorithm group the results into the ideal number of clusters (determined by the silhouette method), and we will see how closely the resultant clusters track our hypothesized ones?  That is, does K-means produce three clusters?  And do those clusters accord with the hypothesized clusters of: law abiding = White female, malum prohibitum crimes = White male, malum in se crimes = Black male? 

As exploratory confirmatory analyses, and to satisfy reviewers who might want more traditional statistical methods, we also will run Anova with pairwise comparisons with Bonferroni corrections. 

All R code has been uploaded to OSF along with this preregistration.

outliers.value: If anyone fails the written attention check or indicates that they did not participate properly (we ask them directly), they will be excluded. If a participant is not a US citizen, he or she will be excluded. All excluded participants will still receive compensation.

dependent.value:
For race, the DV is a Likert scale that runs from 1 (definitely Black) to 10 (definitely White).

For sex, the DV is a Likert scale that runs from 1 (definitely Male) to 10 (definitely Female).

conditions.value: Participants will see all 11 CIs and will answer both DVs for each one. The CIs will be presented in randomized order.

hypothesis.value:
Using Princeton undergraduate subjects (N = approximately 40 per condition), we used facial reverse correlation to generate 11 classification images (CIs): one each for the conditions of "law abiding", "criminal", "bank fraud offender", "insider trader", "assault offender", "burglar", "murderer", "malum prohibitum", "malum in se". 

In the present study, we are testing these CIs on two dimensions: race and sex. We hypothesize that, one, criminality will be masculine (law-abiding will be female and criminal will be male). Two, criminal subtypes will parse along a racial (White/Black) line in accordance with the malum prohibitum/in se distinction. That is, participants will imagine a criminal who is not immoral as a White male (bank fraud offender, insider trader) and a criminal who is immoral as a Black male (burglar, murderer, assault offender).

attributes.title: Organizational Learning from or with Community

q1.value: Organizational Learning From or With Community

q3.value:
Background: Though extant literatures frequently contain normative statements about community engagement—through customer relationships in business, or patient involvement in healthcare, for instance—the tendency is to refer to organizational learning from these interactions in the abstract, obscuring our understanding of the structures, processes, implications and outcomes of organizational learning from or with communities. The community and its members represent an invaluable source of knowledge about the performance of the organization. They also represent a social context in which the organization is embedded, including established norms and worldviews the organization must navigate in order to benefit the community at individual and collective levels.  

Question: What is known in extant literatures (grey literature and academic) about organizational learning from or with community?

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Scoping review methodology as described in attached protocol.

q10.value: Registration following analysis of the data

q11.value: Scoping review protocol was written in advance of completion of study and was first loaded onto OSF in June 2019. Registration in 2019 unable to be completed due to technical problems.

question.value:
Literature search: First, we conducted an initial search in Scopus to identify journals with the highest number of relevant publications, then searched a global directory (ulrichsweb.com) to locate databases where these journals were indexed. The initial academic search strategy was developed for Ovid MEDLINE® and then translated for other academic databases. Several preliminary, iterative searches permitted us to refine a multi-stranded search using a combination of subject headings and text words for the three primary concepts, and tailor our strategy to each database. Final searches with no language or date limits were conducted on March 19, 2019 in Ovid MEDLINE® (1946-Present), PsycINFO (1806 to March Week 2 2019), CINAHL Plus with Full Text, ERIC, Web of Science Core Collection and Business Source Premier. The full search equation for each academic database is found in Appendix A. To supplement the academic database search, CM hand searched all issues of two journals, The Learning Organization and Learning Health Systems, finding 11 potentially eligible citations.
We also searched online using numerous combinations of key terms in Advanced Google Search and Duck Duck Go. CM reviewed search results up to five webpages after the last hit; ten potentially eligible citations were found. CM also reviewed the websites of four organizations  well known for their contributions to the study of learning health systems and found three potentially eligible citations by browsing and searching for publications. When multiple publications were available as part of a series, the most recent or summative publication was chosen. In the case of one evidence synthesis publication found in this way, CM found ten additional potentially eligible citations through reference tracking. All potentially eligible citations were loaded into EndNote X9.1.1 for deduplication.

Searchable concepts: We developed a broad search strategy based on three primary concepts: organizational learning, including social learning; the learning organization, comprising organizational learning, organizational knowledge and knowledge management and including learning health systems; and community, comprising community knowledge and involvement.  

Eligibility criteria: 
•	Either description of interaction between an organization and a community or description of knowledge transfer from a community to an organization as a means to contribute to organizational learning, change or innovation;
•	Reference to ‘learning,’ either through description of organizational learning structures, processes or outcomes or description of elements of a learning organization or learning health system;
•	Description of the relationship between the organization and community as one in which the community should benefit from organizational outputs;
•	Description of learning as occurring at the level of the organization.
Provided they met these criteria, citations were included based on an inclusive understanding of ‘community’ (e.g., client, customer, patient, consumer, public). Citations were excluded if they focused on interorganizational learning or professional communities of practice; described learning at a level other than the organization; were written in a language other than English; or offered insufficient evidence, typically because they were book reviews or short commentaries. All criteria were piloted against 10 purposively selected journal articles and refined before any screening.

Restrictions: No restrictions were included in the searches.

Study selection: First phase screening of the literature search results was completed by two reviewers (CM, DW) using Rayyan, a web-based screening tool. Before screening began, pilot tests of the eligibility criteria and web-based tool on a preselected list of 27 citations were conducted by both reviewers, helping to refine the screening help sheet found in Appendix B. Over four rounds, the two reviewers screened the titles and abstracts of 524 (27%) citations with the objective to reach consistent inter-rater agreement above 80%. Agreement in each successive round was 74%, 81%, 83% and 92%, respectively, with conflicts resolved through discussion. CM screened the remaining 1,423 (73%) titles and abstracts independently. Where there was not enough or unclear information to exclude a citation, the citation was included for full-text review. In total, 98 citations were screened in and their full texts were reviewed against the eligibility criteria by CM and DW. Disagreements were resolved by consensus. One additional citation was included at this stage after reviewing the reference lists of all full-text documents. 

Data extraction: Using a pre-set chart in Excel that was pilot tested on a sample of five included texts, CM extracted data with regard to numerous variables including article characteristics (e.g., discipline, study design, objective, findings); theoretical frameworks and definitions; dimensions of learning (e.g., processes, structures, goals, outcomes); and community variables (e.g., conceptualization of community and community roles). Data related to power relations and ethical tensions were also extracted on the basis that organizations and communities could face power differentials and ethical ambiguities in their learning relationship.

It explicitly describes methodology for this relatively new type of review, and the methods can be applied to prognostic factor reviews in other areas, as well as this specific project.

q1.value: Gender differences in perceived social support and mental well-being among Type 1 diabetics.

q3.value: Social support refers to the perceived judgement of support that is provided by a network of others during times of need. Literature grounds itself on the positive influence of social support, House, Landis and Umberson (1980) stated that health is optimal when social support networks are larger with greater quality support from its members. Social networking impacts the well-being and quality of life of individuals who have access to support systems and social networks. Research has shown a decrease in rates of depression, loneliness and risk of mortality (Blumenthal, et al. 2006; Christian & D'Auria, 2006; House, Lanids & Umberson, 1988). More literature highlights the effects of social support on health by looking at associations of morbidity and mortality, even those with chronic conditions e.g. dialysis, cancer, diabetes etc. who receive greater support have better predictions of greater physical health. Research from Gleeson-Kreig, Bernhal and Wooley (2002) in a chronically ill sample underlined the effect of structured support in the activated of self-management behaviours, particularly greater eating habits, exercise, adherence to medications and attendance to appointments. This was also supported by improved diabetes control and capability of coping with stress (Dam, et al. 2005; Griffith, Field and Lustman, 1990).  This is a great example of the effective influence of social support networks, particularly in with chronic illnesses who are target to experiencing greater stress. Social support is influenced by many factors, gender being one of those, Reevy and Maslach (2001) found women had greater emotional support than men, similarly in stressful scenarios (Day & Livingstone, 2003). The purpose of this study is to explore the role of gender and the perception of available social support and mental well-being when looking at those with a chronic illness such as Type 1 diabetes. The benefit to look at gender differences within a type 1 diabetic sample, if there is a difference, it would be important to implement interventions for those (men or women) who lack social support when living with a chronic illness. This could be essential for the future well-being and coping behaviours of Type 1 diabetics that can positively impact their condition and mental health.

q4.value: It is hypothesised that the size of the social support system will mediate the relationship between gender and mental well-being. Women will have a greater social support system than men and this, in turn, leads them to have score higher mental well-being.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
A quantitative independent groups design will be used. The independent variable will be gender with 2 levels (male and female), and the dependent variables will be gender and self-reported mental well-being. A sample will be recruited according to the inclusion criteria, these include an official diagnosis of Type 1 diabetes and aged 18 or over.  Participants will be recruited online via adverts distributed on social media sites and forums relating to Type 1 diabetes. 
The online survey using Qualtrics will involve questions that allow participants to list members using their initials within their social support. From the list provided, participants will be asked follow up questions regarding the type of support each member provides, this will follow the supportive functions of interpersonal relationships (Willis, 1985), "emotional", "instrumental", "informational" and "appraisal" type support.  The second half of the survey will include two already existing questionnaires. The 12-item Multidimensional Scale of Perceived Social Support (MSPSS, 1988) a well validated measure (Zimet, Dahlem, Zimet, & Farley, 1988) of perceived support with three sub-scales, friends, family and  a significant other, which uses a seven point Likert scale (1, very strongly disagree – 7, very strongly agree).
Also, the 14 item Warwick Edinburgh Mental Well-Being Scale (WEMWBS, 2007) will be used as a measure of mental well-being, using a five Likerk scale (1, none of the time – 5, all of the time), which accurately assesses the positive attributes of mental health (Tennant, Hiller, Fishwick, Platt, et al. 2007).

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited using online platforms such as diabetic communities or forums social media sites such as Facebook, Instagram or websites such as Diabetes UK, Diabetes Daily, JDRF or PatientsLikeMe. They will be provided with an advertisement which includes a brief outline of why the study is being carries out, what it will entail, how long it is expected to take and acknowledgement it has been approved by the ethics committee at Northumbria University Newcastle. The advertisement will also include a link to the online survey if they choose to participate which will take them to the Qualtrics site.  Due to the nature of the recruitment strategy, international participants are able to take part in the study as long as they meet the criteria of participation (over the age of 18 and have an official diagnosis of Type 1 diabetes).  There will be no reward for taking part in this study but participants are thanked for their time. The study will be closed and data will stop being collected February 28th 2020.

q13.value: The target sample 70 participants, we will attempt to recruit over 100 participants assuming that not all participants will accurately complete the survey.

question.value: The independent variable will be gender with 2 levels (male and female) which will be asked at the beginning of the survey to identify the gender of the participant. The dependent variables will be social support which will be measured using self-reported support groups as well as the Multidimensional Scale of Perceived Social Support and self-reported mental well-being using the Warwick Edinburgh Mental Wellbeing Scale.

Data will be analysed using a 1 way independent ANOVA to determine effects of the IV (gender) on the DVs (mental well-being and perceived social support), against a null hypothesis in order to establish a mediation effect. Statistically significant differences will be assessed using F and P values. If results are significant, post-hoc tests will be used to analyse differences between groups, i.e. male and female on mental well-being and perceived social support. In order to establish if there is a relationship between mental well-being and perceived social support, a bi-variate correlation will be ran using Pearson’s r to establish a positive or negative relationship between these variables. 

My thesis supervisor might use a different set of analyses and these might be the ones used if the project is published. These might consist of regressions and network analyses.

Statistical significance at p<.05

q23.value: If the survey has not been fully completed, then the data provided will not be used or included in the analysis.

q24.value: My supervisor might use these data for exploratory analyses and use a different set of methods.

registration_responses.q3: Social support refers to the perceived judgement of support that is provided by a network of others during times of need. Literature grounds itself on the positive influence of social support, House, Landis and Umberson (1980) stated that health is optimal when social support networks are larger with greater quality support from its members. Social networking impacts the well-being and quality of life of individuals who have access to support systems and social networks. Research has shown a decrease in rates of depression, loneliness and risk of mortality (Blumenthal, et al. 2006; Christian & D'Auria, 2006; House, Lanids & Umberson, 1988). More literature highlights the effects of social support on health by looking at associations of morbidity and mortality, even those with chronic conditions e.g. dialysis, cancer, diabetes etc. who receive greater support have better predictions of greater physical health. Research from Gleeson-Kreig, Bernhal and Wooley (2002) in a chronically ill sample underlined the effect of structured support in the activated of self-management behaviours, particularly greater eating habits, exercise, adherence to medications and attendance to appointments. This was also supported by improved diabetes control and capability of coping with stress (Dam, et al. 2005; Griffith, Field and Lustman, 1990).  This is a great example of the effective influence of social support networks, particularly in with chronic illnesses who are target to experiencing greater stress. attributes.title: To Invest, to Save, or to Contribute to Your Retirement Fund?

q1.value: Investing, saving, or contributing: Which frame promotes increases in retirement savings?

q3.value:
Some financial researchers have concluded that America is in a "retirement crisis:" people are not putting away enough money into their retirement funds to be able to achieve financial independence after they retire (Benartzi & Thaler, 2013). 

Retirement preparation has been conveyed through a number of frames, largely as either saving for retirement, contributing to one's retirement funds, or investing in retirement. Whether the effect of such wording affects people's retirement planning habits, however, is unknown. Thus, I will measure the effects of retirement preparation frames (invest vs. save vs. contribute) on retirement savings motivation and behavior.

q4.value:
Hypothesis 1a: 

Framing retirement preparation as an "investment" (vs. as "saving" or "contributing") will increase the amount of money people would like to deposit into their retirement planning.  

In Study 1, support for this hypothesis will be evidenced by people's decisions to spend less in their working years and more in their retirement. In Study 2, support for the hypothesis will be evidenced by higher allocations of money to a retirement fund. 

Hypothesis 1b: 

Framing retirement preparation as an "investment" (vs. as "saving" or "contributing") will lead people to report that they plan on increasing (vs. decreasing or keeping constant) their retirement fund deposits in the next month. 

Hypothesis 2: 

Framing retirement preparation as an "investment" (vs. as "saving" or "contributing") will increase people's motivation to discuss retirement planning with their social network.

Hypothesis 3: 

The more important that people find retirement preparation to be, the more likely they are to select an option entailing spending more in retirement (vs. during the working years; Study 1),  the more they will allot to a retirement fund (Study 2), and be more motivated to increase their retirement fund deposits in the next month.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: Between subjects design with 1 factor (retirement planning frame) and three levels (investing, saving, contributing).

q9.value: Each participant will be randomly assigned to one of the three conditions based on the random  number algorithm of Survey Gizmo (software used to collect data).

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited via MTurk. They will be paid $0.36 for their time. This value was determined by dividing the U.S. federal minimum wage ($7.25) by 60 to compute how much the compensation should be by minute ($0.12/minute); and then by multiplying this value by SurveyGizmo's estimate of how long it will take people to complete the study (3 minutes). Thus: $0.36 = ($7.25 / 60) * 3

q13.value: The target sample size is 700 for each study (n = 1400 total).

q14.value:
I conducted a power analysis in G*Power. The software is unable to compute power analyses for nonparametric tests that are going to be used in the analyses in this research. I thus determined power by using an F distribution from a one-way ANOVA (the parametric analog to the nonparametric Kruskal-Wallis test to examine the hypothesis). 

I assumed 80% power, a .05 alpha, and an effect size partial eta squared = .015 (value based on prior although non registered investigations).

q15.value: Data collection will stop as soon as the desired sample size is reached.

question.value: The manipulated variable will be the frame of depositing into a retirement fund. People will read a paragraph that encourages people to deposit money into their retirement fund by framing the deposit as an investment in, savings for, or contribution to one's retirement.

Both studies will contain the following measures: 

After participants read the passage (the IV), they will answer the question: 

Study 1's main dependent measure was used originally by Binswanger & Carman (2012). In this task, people select one of six options that present a tradeoff between the amount of money one would spend monthly prior to retirement and the amount of money one spends after retirement. Three options entail spending more during the working years than during retirement; one option keeps spending constant across both career stages; and two options entail spending less during the working years than during retirement. The latter two options reflect motivation to increase one's deposit into their retirement fund.

Study 2's main dependent measure is based on a task developed by Hershfield et al. (2011). In this task, participants read the following instructions: "Imagine that you had just unexpectedly received $1,000. How much of this money would you allocate to each of the following options? Keep in mind that your numbers should add to 1,000." Participants will then see five different options: Use it to buy something nice for someone special; invest it in a retirement fund (the DV), put it into a savings account; use it to buy something nice for myself; plan a fun and extravagant occasion.

Both studies will include an additional DV: whether people believe that they will decrease, keep constant, or increase their retirement deposit in the next month. 

Other measured variables include how important people find financial planning to be; how important retirement preparation is to people's financial planning; how often they thought about retirement preparation; and whether they will discuss retirement preparation with their social network in the next week. 

A document with all measures to be used in this research is attached.
NA

I will be using a Kruskal-Wallis test of between-group differences (non-parametric analog of a one-way ANOVA). Post-hoc analyses  will consist of a set of Mann-Whitney U tests (non-parametric analogs of the Student's t-test)—I will set the statistical significance criterion in these tests to be p <= .0167 (.05 / 3) to reduce Type 1 error in multiple comparisons. I will report effect sizes for each test. 

To preserve statistical power, all tests will be one-tailed per the directional hypotheses.

q21.value: I will use the standard statistical significance criterion of p <.05. For any post-hoc test, I will re-set the significance criterion to be .05 divided by the number of tests (thus, the "statistical significance" p-values for post-hoc will be p < .0167).

q22.value:
-Anyone who reports to be less than 18 years of age will be removed; likewise, anyone who reports an abnormally high age (e.g., 99) will also be removed. 

-Participants who incorrectly complete the money allocation task (i.e., total allocated exceeds 1,000) will be removed.

-Participants will be removed if they fail to correctly answer the attention-checking question "What is two plus five?"

-Participants will be removed if they answer "yes" to the following question assessing honesty: 

"Realistically, we understand that people may not always be completely honest in their responses to surveys. Honesty in responses is very important to us because it allows us to get a clear view of how people think, feel, and behave. Judging by how honest you think you were in your responses, should we keep your answers for our analyses? You’ll be paid for your time either way."

q23.value: Missing data will be ignored from analyses on a case by case basis, as some participants may provide responses on several measures, choosing not to answer other measures. If a participant provided a response to at least one DV, they will remain in the analyses of that DV but will be excluded from analyses of variables that they did not complete.

q24.value: Exploratory results will consist of correlation analyses between all variables in used in the study. All of these tests will be tested using a two-tailed p value.

q25.value:
Citations:

Benartzi, S., & Thaler, R. H. (2013). Behavioral economics and the retirement savings crisis. Science, 339, 1152-1153. DOI: 10.1126/science.1231320

Binswanger, J., & Carman, K. G. (2012). How real people make long-term decisions: The c age of retirement preparation. Journal of Economic Behavior & Organization, 81, 39-60. DOI: 10.1016/j.jebo.2011.08.010

Hershfield, H. E., Goldstein, D. G., Sharpe, W. F., Fox, J., Yeykelis, L., Carstensen, L. L., & Bailenson, J. M. (2011). Increasing saving behavior through age-progressed renderings of the future self. Journal of Marketing Research, 48, S23-S37. DOI: 10.1509/jmkr.48.SPL.S23.

attributes.title: Cytochrome P450 2D6 (CYP2D6) activity in patients with Codeine Use Disorder
attributes.description: A study of the prevalence of CYP2D6 ultra metabolisers in a population of people with codeine use disorder/dependence.

q1.value: Cytochrome P450 2D6 (CYP2D6) activity in patients with Codeine Use Disorder.

q2.value: Sarah Reilly, Mark Daglish, jeremy hayllar, Chiyan Lau

q3.value: Codeine is the most prescribed opioid in Australia. Alcohol and Other Drug (AOD) services have seen substantial numbers of clients with primary codeine use disorder (CUD). Medication Assisted Treatment for Opioid Dependence (MATOD) with replacement opioids is a common treatment option. Studies have highlighted the difficulty with opioid replacement dose estimation in patients with CUD. This may reflect the inconsistent manner in which codeine is metabolised to morphine via the Cytochrome P450 2D6 (CYPD2D6) sub system. CYP2D6 enzyme expression is variable and genetically determined; "normal" metabolisers (NM) have 2 copies of the active form of CYP2D6 but ultra-rapid metabolisers (UM) have multiple copies causing them to produce greater quantities of morphine from codeine. In contrast, low normal, intermediate and poor metabolisers (LNM, IM, PM) have reduced CYP2D6 activity. This project will explore the role of pharmacogenomics in CUD by examining CYP2D6 genotype in a CUD treatment group.

q4.value:
1.	There will be a higher prevalence of efficient codeine metabolisers i.e. NM & UM in clients with codeine use disorder than in the general population.  
2.	UM patients will require higher doses of buprenorphine proportionate to their stated codeine intake to stabilise their codeine use disorder.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: This is a cohort study comparing a newly collected sample of people with a codeine use disorder (CUD) to previously published population data.  We will recruit clients from Australian metropolitan Alcohol & Other Drug (AOD) clinics. The primary inclusion criterion is a diagnosis of CUD for at least one service episode. Additionally, all participants will be adults (at least 18 years of age), whose CUD was treated with opioid replacement therapy; either methadone or buprenorphine. Clients will be excluded if codeine was not the primary drug of concern.  Participants must also be capable of providing informed consent to participate. For the primary analysis the patient cohort will be split into two groups, UM+NM and LNM+IM+PM.  Proportions will be compared with those published in a large Australian control sample of CYPD2D6 genotype prevalence in the general population (Mostafa, S., et al., An analysis of allele, genotype and phenotype frequencies, actionable pharmacogenomic (PGx) variants and phenoconversion in 5408 Australian patients genotyped for CYP2D6, CYP2C19, CYP2C9 and VKORC1 genes. Journal of Neural Transmission, 2019. 126(1): p. 5-18).

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

q11.value: The control general population data is drawn from a previously published paper (Mostafa, S., et al., An analysis of allele, genotype and phenotype frequencies, actionable pharmacogenomic (PGx) variants and phenoconversion in 5408 Australian patients genotyped for CYP2D6, CYP2C19, CYP2C9 and VKORC1 genes. Journal of Neural Transmission, 2019. 126(1): p. 5-18).

question.value:
1.	Research project setting
1.1.	Potential participants will be recruited from clients receiving MATOD treatment who have at least one treatment episode for a CUD at two Australian metropolitan AODS clinics. 
2.	Recruitment:
2.1.  Participants will be approached by clinics staff to ask if they would like to discuss involvement with a clinic doctor.  Recruiting doctors will provide verbal and written information on the study aims, methods and requirements.  Participants will receive a $30 Coles voucher for participation.  
3.	Data collection
3.1.	DNA samples for genotyping
Consenting clients will provide a single buccal swab for DNA analysis of CYP2D6 genotype.  Genotyping will be conducted in the same laboratory as the previously published population data.
3.2.	Clinical & demographic information
Basic demographic data on age and gender along with clinical information on CUD (maximum and usual daily codeine dose, duration of CUD) and MATOD treatment (OST medication, initial stabilisation, peak and current maintenance doses, treatment duration) will be extracted from the case notes at the clinic.

q13.value: Our target sample size is a minimum of 40 clients.  Larger samples will provide increased power for the primary analysis and more detailed secondary analyses.  The population sample previously published that will be used as a control group contains just over 5,400 samples.

q14.value: The aim is to recruit as many clients as possible up to a maximum of 90 clients which is the maximum permissible within the study budget.  For the primary analysis the patient cohort will be split into two groups, UM+NM and LNM+IM+PM.  Proportions will be compared with the published population data (Mostafa, S., et al). The minimum clinically meaningful level was set as an increase of at least 20% in the proportion of patients in the UM+NM group compared to the general population.  This requires a sample size of at least 35-40 patients to compare to the population sample of 5,400 for a power of 80% to detect a difference with statistical significance set at p less than 0.05 using binomial distribution calculations.  If a larger sample is collected then a secondary ordinal analysis will be undertaken using all 5 phenotypes and a suitable non-parametric test which has lower power.

q15.value: The study budget will permit recruitment of up to 90 participants.

question.value:
1.	Outcome measures.
1.1.	The primary outcome measure is CYP2D6 genotype status. Genotypes will be converted to 5 categories (UM, NM, LNM, IM, PM) using published criteria (Mostafa et al).
2.	Secondary outcome measures will be treatment variables:
2.1.	Buprenorphine or methadone daily doses during the index treatment episode at the time points: – end of stabilisation, defined as the dose when transferred from the clinic to community pharmacy dosing; maximum dose ever prescribed during the index treatment episode; and current daily dose if still in the index treatment episode.
2.2.	Duration the client was prescribed buprenorphine or methadone from the commencement of treatment for CUD until the earlier of treatment completion of the index treatment episode or the date of DNA sampling. 
3.	Predictor Variables
3.1.	Demographics – age at the commencement of the index episode of treatment for CUD and gender.
3.2.	CUD descriptors 
3.2.1.	Current episode duration defined as the length of time the client has been continuously using codeine with a break of less than 2 weeks up to entry into treatment for the index episode of treatment.
3.2.2.	Total duration of CUD defined as the age of onset of problematic codeine use identified by the client up to the age at entry into treatment for the index episode.
3.2.3.	Maximum daily codeine dose defined as the mean daily consumption of codeine during the period of lifetime heaviest use.
3.2.4.	Current daily codeine dose defined as the mean daily consumption of codeine during the month immediately preceding the index treatment episode.

1.	The primary statistical analysis will be a one-tailed 2x2 Wilcoxon-Mann Whitney test comparing the proportions of efficient (UM+NM) and inefficient (LNM+IM+PM) CYP2D6 metabolisers between the study sample and the published general population sample.  Our primary hypothesis predicts that the proportion of efficient metabolisers will be significantly increased in the CUD sample compared to the general population sample.
2.	This test will be repeated in a one-tailed 2x5 Wilcoxon-Mann Whitney test comparing the proportions across all the ordinal genotype categories (UM, NM, LNM, IM, PM).
3.	The secondary hypothesis that CYP2D6 status will influence the relationship between codeine use and subsequent treatment medication dose will be tested by regression analysis.  The primary analysis for this hypothesis will use linear regression to compare UM with NM where mean codeine dose prior to treatment and CYP2D6 status are the predictor variables and the stabilisation dose of buprenorphine as defined in the measures section is the dependent variable.  This analysis will be restricted to the subset of clients with genotypes UM & NM who were treated with buprenorphine.  The hypothesis predicts that UM clients will require higher doses of buprenorphine than NM clients with similar levels of codeine use.

q20.value:
1.	For Wilcoxon-Mann Whitney tests CYP2D6 genotypes will be assigned ranks: UM=5, NM=4, LNM=3, IM=2, PM=1.
2.	Where CYP2D6 genotypes are combined into 2 groups these will be dummy coded as UM+NM=1, LNM+IM+PM=0.
3.	Where CYP2D6 genotypes are used in the regression analysis they will be dummy coded as NM=0, UM=1 and NM will be considered the reference category.
4.	In all cases where general population data is included this will be the reference category.

q21.value: P-values will be used to infer statistical significance.  Standard p less than 0.05 criteria for determining significant results.  One-tailed tests will be used where the hypotheses specify a direction of results.

q22.value: If extreme outliers are identified, then analyses will be repeated with & without the outliers and both sets of results reported.

q23.value: Clients with missing data will be excluded on a case-wise basis for each test.

registration_responses.q1: Cytochrome P450 2D6 (CYP2D6) activity in patients with Codeine Use Disorder.
registration_responses.q2: Sarah Reilly, Mark Daglish, jeremy hayllar, Chiyan Lau
registration_responses.q3: Codeine is the most prescribed opioid in Australia. Alcohol and Other Drug (AOD) services have seen substantial numbers of clients with primary codeine use disorder (CUD). Medication Assisted Treatment for Opioid Dependence (MATOD) with replacement opioids is a common treatment option. Studies have highlighted the difficulty with opioid replacement dose estimation in patients with CUD. This may reflect the inconsistent manner in which codeine is metabolised to morphine via the Cytochrome P450 2D6 (CYPD2D6) sub system. CYP2D6 enzyme expression is variable and genetically determined; "normal" metabolisers (NM) have 2 copies of the active form of CYP2D6 but ultra-rapid metabolisers (UM) have multiple copies causing them to produce greater quantities of morphine from codeine. In contrast, low normal, intermediate and poor metabolisers (LNM, IM, PM) have reduced CYP2D6 activity. This project will explore the role of pharmacogenomics in CUD by examining CYP2D6 genotype in a CUD treatment group.
registration_responses.q4:
1.	There will be a higher prevalence of efficient codeine metabolisers i.e. NM & UM in clients with codeine use disorder than in the general population.  
2.	UM patients will require higher doses of buprenorphine proportionate to their stated codeine intake to stabilise their codeine use disorder.

q6: No blinding is involved in this study.

registration_responses.q8.question: This is a cohort study comparing a newly collected sample of people with a codeine use disorder (CUD) to previously published population data.  We will recruit clients from Australian metropolitan Alcohol & Other Drug (AOD) clinics. The primary inclusion criterion is a diagnosis of CUD for at least one service episode. Additionally, all participants will be adults (at least 18 years of age), whose CUD was treated with opioid replacement therapy; either methadone or buprenorphine. Clients will be excluded if codeine was not the primary drug of concern.  Participants must also be capable of providing informed consent to participate. For the primary analysis the patient cohort will be split into two groups, UM+NM and LNM+IM+PM.  Proportions will be compared with those published in a large Australian control sample of CYPD2D6 genotype prevalence in the general population (Mostafa, S., et al., An analysis of allele, genotype and phenotype frequencies, actionable pharmacogenomic (PGx) variants and phenoconversion in 5408 Australian patients genotyped for CYP2D6, CYP2C19, CYP2C9 and VKORC1 genes. Journal of Neural Transmission, 2019. 126(1): p. 5-18).
